--- In junit@yahoogroups.com, "J. B. Rainsberger" <jbrains@r...> 
wrote:
> jonbyrne1254 wrote:
> > 
> > 
> > Hi all,
> > Im currently using a very powerful test tool but the problem is 
that it
> > produces unreadable results. It takes an input file executes all 
the
> > attribute values and throws an exception if there is an error. 
There
> > are about 150+ of these files. To fix it up I wrapped it in 
Junit. Now
> > each executed file is treated as an individual test. This works 
great,
> > I have a nice gui telling me which testfiles passed and which 
failed.
> > The problem is that it doesnt tell me why they fail. the original
> > program still throws an exception but Junit cannot hear it. Is 
there
> > any way of directing the error to Junit? thanks Jonno
> 
> It depends how you wrapped with JUnit. If you wrap each file in a 
test, 
> then does your test handle exceptions thrown from the file? If so, 
don't 
> handle the exceptions, and JUnit will handle them for you.
> 
> I would need to see code to give better advice.
> -- 
> J. B. (Joe) Rainsberger
> Diaspar Software Services
> http://www.diasparsoftware.com
> Author, JUnit Recipes: Practical Methods for Programmer Testing

I took out the exception handling and that did it, but I think this 
might not be the best way to go about it. I`m going to go and do a 
bit of redesign. Thanks for the help anyway, its much appreciated.
